comments.commentBody: Making this for a casual dinner party--what would you drink with this?

I'm making this tonight for a small dinner party and will be serving Kabinett Riesling from Mosel and Oregon Pinot Noir.  Other options would be Mencia from Ribiera Sacra for a red or Gruner Veltliner from Kamptal for the white.  Hope this helps!
thank you!

'carmelized' means the liquid will dry up and the food (in this case cabbage) will change colors, getting browned in spots as the sugar goes through a chemical change.  since the cabbage here has the addition of molasses, a sticky sweetener, it has a helper in the process.  don't leave this alone on the stove once the liquid is almost gone; stir and scrape up the cabbage until you will see a dramatic difference in the color of the cabbage and in the smell.

Though it is British, not Swedish, Lyle's Golden Syrup is should do the job. It is available at most upscale grocery stores and on-line: <https://search.yahoo.com/yhs/search?p=lyle%27s+golden+syrup+where+to+buy...
I thought that myself.  I need to use up my jar of Lyle's.  Thanks for the reminder.
I agree that it looks like too much for an 8x8 pan. However, I used a Lodge 10 inch cast iron frying pan to bake it in, and it was fine. It was to the top when I put it in, but it cooks down.

Reparations are a great idea, Ross, but $10,000 is a paltry sum that doesn't begin to address the substantial discrepancies in wealth between whites and blacks, which is many times greater than the discrepancies in earnings.  As for  affirmative action. Improving schools in poor communities, expanding early childhood education, providing quality affordable childcare would probably go a long way towards eliminating the need for affirmative action, but would cost way more money.
Yes. Perhaps $300,000? But probably better to invest in education, childcare, affordable housing, enlightened policing, and infrastructure.

I used a wok for my cabbage, which worked great (it also happened to be the only pan that was big enough to contain all the cabbage, initially. I had used a rather big head of cabbage.). At some point, a lot of nice-looking soup pooled at the bottom, which I poured into a bowl, and used later instead of the stock/water.
And I used maple syrup instead of molasses, and it was delicious. I am not very fond of sugar in my savory dishes, so I used little over half the quantity in the recipe.
Thank you. I'm not too fond of sugar in savory dishes, either, and was going to ask of anyone who'd made this how "sweet" it is. How did cutting the molasses/syrup in half work out?

It was delicious. It took me much longer than 25 minutes to cook the cabbage down.
I put a 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg in the meat mixture.
took me a longer time, too

I sniffed my jar of Four Spice which has nutmeg and opted instead for a bit of thyme and some Dijon in the meat mixture.

I too gave up on cooking down the cabbage after about 45 minutes
At some point I took half of the cabbage out of my Dutch oven as it needed more room if it was going to caramelize. The second batch had plenty of liquid left, so this worked out quite nicely.

Complex and tasty flavor. I will make it again, with these notes: Because of allergies, subbed canola oil for butter in cabbage, skipped the cream entirely and subbed bread crumbs with crushed rice crispies. Had to broil it to get the cabbage caramelized. Next time will skip the baking and go straight to broiling or bake at 500 for shorter time. Mixed all of cabbage into meat. Did not bother with adding liquid before baking. As I said, complex yum! Thanks for the recipe.
Yep, I had to use a larger rectangular pyrex dish.

File this under "scrumptious"...so many wonderful flavours in what is a wonderful traditional comfort food from Sweden.  We woke up to several fresh inches of snow this morning and the temperature had dropped down again.  Perfect kind of day for this.
I think they meant two studies on how biotin affects nails, not two studies on anything to do with biotin.

Grandma said to eat ordinary unflavored gelatin to keep nails strong. Grandma had long, elegant nails until she died at age 89. When I noticed my nails were splitting I started eating 1 tablespoon of gelatin daily. Once my nails grew out (about a month) they were much stronger and no longer split. In addition, my hair got thicker and stopped splitting. My stronger hair took about 2 years to grow in completely.

Actually the issue is deficiency in trace minerals...which through a hair analysis you find low on most people. I am an acupuncturist and herbalist. I use Standard Process Trace minerals/B12 and find that within about  3 mos you do have results. Standard Process is whole food organic vitamins from a 100 year old company out of Wisconsin. Will have to get from a practitioner but well worth it.
No comparison in importance, I wash my hands all the time to prevent illness. I may start using hand lotion on my nails, it never occurred to me to do that, but I certainly won't stop handwashing.

I had a nail which split longways before it reached the end of the finger.
This went on for many years.Someone suggested a zinc tablet which I had daily for about 2 weeks and from then on 1 per month did the trick.Has never come back.

I am 66 years old and in the last few years my nails have become ridged and brittle so they are hard to clip, even though I have a good clipper. I recently started using a glass (or "crystal") nail file and it's solving my problem. It is much finer than my metal nail file, so it makes my nails much smoother. But it also can make them shorter quickly, so I'm using it instead of a clipper.
I do the same, using a crystal nail file and it really helps.  No longer use a clipper, just like you.
Flaxseed meal or oil, chia seeds, salmon, anything with omega-3s does the trick. I put flaxseed or chia in my cereal every day.

The article also states that we can't get enough biotin to replicate the doses in the trial from foods, so switching to paleo has no evidence it would someone's nail health (not that the studies that saw improvements with biotin seem great to begin with).

Besides, those foods are mainstays of many diets, so I'm not sure what your point is.
I have brittle nails but it doesn't make me depressed.
Underactive thyroid disease also causes nails to be thin and dry which may be the reason they split more easily.
I know most people don't have any extra time, but if you watch the evening news anyway, you could soak at the same time.

Sorry guys -- over many years I have used biotin and not used biotin and the biotin clearly works on my nails -- period.

As to price, one needs to be a conscious consumer and compare prices/sizes. Just plain "biotin" can be obtained relatively cheaply but brands claiming to be "nail fixers" of some sort, for instance, run 4-5 times more than just "biotin' from the vitamin/supplement shelves.

Another negative article against natural healthcare solutions by the NYT, citing those who do not have the faintest idea, that yes, nutrition does play an essential role in splitting nails, and that while supplements may be useful, the diet is also important, And of course, we have the up front acid comment about supplements being over-priced, as if standard conventional medical care in the USA were not even more overpriced.

I don't understand your comment. The article states, "30 micrograms of the B vitamin" a day is an amount "easily obtained from diet". If that isn't the most "natural healthcare solution" to prevent nail splitting, what is? Who are "those who do not have the faintest idea"? Who are apparently backing up your statement that nutrition and diet are important. Who are you railing against?

I am an OB/Gyn and I really strive to make sure my patients are informed. If you watch carefully for the patients reaction, it is often clear that understanding is not there. If I have other patients waiting I provide written information ( all patients get written materials in my clinic) and advise the patient that we should talk again at another appointment and invite the patient to bring a friend or family member. I wish there was more time to discuss.
I work in a public clinic so resources are limited and there are a lot of patients. I am paid by a base salary with no bonus or additional income for my work. I work in that setting rather than one that would provide a higher salary because helping my patients is my passion and the satisfaction I feel about what I'm doing is more than money can buy.

I'm going to print the article and put it in my exam rooms, or at least something of the sort. I WANT my patients to understand what is happening. It is imperative to me that my patients receive care equal to that of any privately insured or wealthy patient. I work very hard to maintain up to date knowledge and surgical skills. It saddens me to see so many negative perceptions of us docs. Some people are not wrong in their negative opinion and that saddens me even more.
